coredata.dc:title: Modeling of organic solar cell using response surface methodology
coredata.dc:creator: Suliman, Rajab
Mitul, Abu Farzan
Mohammad, Lal
Djira, Gemechis
Pan, Yunpeng
Qiao, Qiquan
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Polymer solar cells have drawn much attention during the past few decades due to their low manufacturing cost and incompatibility for flexible substrates. In solution-processed organic solar cells, the optimal thickness, annealing temperature, and morphology are key components to achieving high efficiency. In this work, response surface methodology (RSM) is used to find optimal fabrication conditions for polymer solar cells. In order to optimize cell efficiency, the central composite design (CCD) with three independent variables polymer concentration, polymer-fullerene ratio, and active layer spinning speed was used. Optimal device performance was achieved using 10.25mg/ml polymer concentration, 0.42 polymer-fullerene ratio, and 1624rpm of active layer spinning speed. The predicted response (the efficiency) at the optimum stationary point was found to be 5.23% for the Poly(diketopyrrolopyrrole-terthiophene) (PDPP3T)/PC60BM solar cells. Moreover, 97% of the variation in the device performance was explained by the best model. Finally, the experimental results are consistent with the CCD prediction, which proves that this is a promising and appropriate model for optimum device performance and fabrication conditions.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Organic photovoltaics
Performance measures
Response surface
Experimental design
Optimization

head.ce:title: Modeling of organic solar cell using response surface methodology

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Polymer solar cells have drawn much attention during the past few decades due to their low manufacturing cost and incompatibility for flexible substrates. In solution-processed organic solar cells, the optimal thickness, annealing temperature, and morphology are key components to achieving high efficiency. In this work, response surface methodology (RSM) is used to find optimal fabrication conditions for polymer solar cells. In order to optimize cell efficiency, the central composite design (CCD) with three independent variables polymer concentration, polymer-fullerene ratio, and active layer spinning speed was used. Optimal device performance was achieved using 10.25mg/ml polymer concentration, 0.42 polymer-fullerene ratio, and 1624rpm of active layer spinning speed. The predicted response (the efficiency) at the optimum stationary point was found to be 5.23% for the Poly(diketopyrrolopyrrole-terthiophene) (PDPP3T)/PC60BM solar cells. Moreover, 97% of the variation in the device performance was explained by the best model. Finally, the experimental results are consistent with the CCD prediction, which proves that this is a promising and appropriate model for optimum device performance and fabrication conditions.

ce:section.ce:para: Renewable energy sources are considered to be clean and a great benefit for the economy and the environment. Solar, winds, geothermal, hydroelectric and bio-mass are the popular renewable energy sources. The sun is a source of enormous energy, and lots of research has been devoted to solar energy conversion. The challenge is to harvest solar energy efficiently at a low manufacturing cost. Solar cell devices based on inorganic semiconductors have been found to collect solar energy more efficiently to produce electricity. However, these are not economically feasible. Organic photovoltaic (OPV) materials offer a promising alternative to solving this problem due to their inherently low cost, abundant availability, and flexibility. Researchers have already made much progress in the development of low cost organic light-emitting diodes, which has opened the path for OPV research.

A solution-processed bulk-heterojunction (BHJ) polymer solar cell not only requires a simpler fabrication technique but also offers a reduced manufacturing cost. Usually, this BHJ solar cell is comprised of electron donating organic semiconductor polymers and electron-withdrawing fullerides as active layers. This composite active layer can be coated over a large area using spray coating, inkjet-coating, and roller-casting. During the last few years, the power conversion efficiency (PCE) of polymer solar cells has improved significantly [1]. The PCE of a solar cell is largely dependent on three major factors: open circuit voltage (Voc), short circuit current (Jsc) and fill factor (FF). The Voc of a solar cell can be determined by the energy difference between the HOMO level of the donor (conjugated polymer or small molecule) and the LUMO level of the acceptor (typically a fullerene derivative). The Jsc can be calculated from the absorption spectrum and absorption depth of the organic donor and the transport of photogenerated carriers through the morphology of the film. During the past few years, researchers have worked to increase the PCE of bulk heterojunction (BHJ) organic solar cells (OSCs) over 9.2%. The active layer of high efficiency devices consists of small bandgap donor-acceptor copolymers as electron donors and fullerene-based derivatives as electron acceptors [2]. Much research is continuing in order to improve device performance since the properties of the materials have a great impact on the overall performance of solar cells [3].

The solar energy conversion in OPV devices mainly follows four major steps: 1) absorption of sunlight by the absorber and generation of excitons; 2) diffusion of the excitons to find donor-acceptor interface, 3) dissociation of the excitons and generation of charges; and 4) charge transport and charge collection. Ideally, polymers should have broad absorption spectra in order to harvest solar energy efficiently. To achieve optimized device performance, polymer concentration, the polymer-fullerene ratio in the solvent, selection of solvent, and thickness of the active layer is important. The electronic properties, crystallinity, maximum charge transport, and minimal recombination within the active layer mainly depend on the fine tuning of the polymer-fullerene mixture [4]. Therefore, the polymer-fullerene mixture, polymer concentration, and active layer thickness can change the optoelectronic properties of the organic solar cells and affect device performance. Also, the individual components have some unique properties, e.g., absorption coefficient, charge carrier mobility, crystalline/amorphous structure, which also significantly influence device performance.

Here, one of useful statistical techniques that are widely used in optimizing the performance of the system is response surface methodology (RSM) [5–9]. RSM is a popular optimization tool that has already been successfully used to optimize many biological and chemical processes. Simultaneous optimization for all factors can be achieved in a systematic manner, such as maximizing solar cell performance and cell thickness, at the same time maintaining the satisfactory characteristics. The aim of present work is to find the optimum device performance through statistical model; RSM was applied to optimize organic solar cell performance to be more efficient and precise.

Poly(diketopyrrolopyrrole-terthiophene) (PDPP3T) was purchased from Solarmer Materials, Inc. PC60BM was ordered from Nano-C. MoO3, Zinc Acetate, Aluminum Nitrate and nonahydrate Ethanol were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Silver was purchased from Kurt J. Lesker Company. All materials were used without further purification. AZO sol-gel was synthesized as described by Stubhan et al. [10]. For the AZO sol-gel synthesis, 2.17g of zinc acetate dehydrate [Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O] and 3.8mg of aluminum nitrate nonahydrate [Al(NO3)3·9H2O] were dissolved in 100ml ethanol at 80°C for 2.5h. Precipitation from the AZO sol-gel was removed using a 0.45µm PVDF filter.

ITO coated glass slides were kept in ultra-sonication for 20min in detergent water. After that, the ITOs were rinsed in de-ionized water and again maintained in ultra-sonication for 20min. Finally, the ITOs were ultra-sonicated in acetone and 2-propanol for another 20min. The ITO substrates were then subjected to oxygen plasma cleaning for 25min before spin-coating with an AZO layer. AZO was spin coated at 4500rpm for 1min and then kept on a hot plate at 150°C for ten minutes to remove residual solvent. The AZO-coated substrates were then moved to a nitrogen-filled glove box having an O2 and H2O concentration of less than 1ppm. The blend of PDPP3T:PCBM solution was spin-coated at different rpm for 45s. Then, the sample was moved to a thermal evaporator where 10nm of MoO3 and 80nm of silver (Ag) were thermally evaporated in a vacuum below 2×10−6 Torr.

An Agilent 4155C semiconductor parameter analyzer was used for the current density-voltage (J–V) characteristic measurements of the solar cell devices. A Newport xenon lamp was used as a solar simulator (AM 1.5). Before performing the characterization of solar cells, a National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) calibrated silicon photo detector was used in order to calibrate the light source. The light source had an intensity of 100mWcm−2. In order to measure the external quantum efficiency (EQE) of the devices, a xenon lamp was attached to a Newport monochromator. Light wavelength from the monochromator was varied from 350nm to 850nm.

Response surface methodology was first introduced by Box and others in the 1950s [11] in the world of chemical industry. RSM is a group of mathematical and statistical procedures used in fitting an empirical model to the experimental data obtained in relation to an experimental design [6]. Consequently, this set of methods has been supplementary developed and advanced with applications in various scientific areas. For more comprehensive details and description about this methodology, we refer to the textbooks, for instance, Khuri and Cornell [12], Box and Draper [13], Myers et al. [14], and Montgomery [15]. In an experimental setting, the choice of design region depends on the required properties expected in the experiment. The classical design properties measured in developing an RSM include orthogonality, rotatability, and uniform precision. For more details, see Khuri and Mukhopadhyay [16].

A Central Composite Design (CCD) is the most popular of all quadratic designs. Generally, this class of designs consists with a full

A CCD is generated in pieces, using the cube, foldover, and star functions to optimize the efficiency from an inverted polymer solar cell [18]. Three independent variables, namely polymer concentration

, investigated at two levels with four replications at the central point. This involves adding values such as star points for rotatability and orthogonal blocking to the complete
2

design. For each of the three factors studied, low (coded value: −1) and high (coded value: +1) set points have been chosen according to the results obtained with polymer solar cell systems, and the required experimental settings were taken into consideration to achieve phase optimization of the efficiency Table 2. All possible combinations that were performed for the central composite design are shown in Table 1
. The analysis was based on combining the
cube
, , foldover, and
star
blocks. For RSM, open source R package (programming language) was used [19,20].

The eight treatment combinations as result of 23 factorial designs can be displayed as a cube, as shown in Fig. 1 . Using the “+ and −” notation as an indication of the high and low levels of each independent variable, all possible combinations of this design are listed in tabular format as described in Table 3 . This tabular is usually called a design matrix [14]. The numbers in the corners of the cube in Fig. 1 represent the observed values of the efficiency associated with the eighth treatment combinations of the 23 factorial designs.

The fitted mathematical model, which is sometimes, not satisfies in describing the experimental region of the independent variable. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) is useful way for evaluating the fitted model [6]. ANOVA is widely used to study the statistical differences between at least three or more independent group means and their associated source of variations (within and between group variations). The results of ANOVA for main effects, quadratic terms, and interactions of obtained data are presented in (Table 5
). Sum of squares is the sum of the squares of the deviation from the mean. Mean Square is an estimate of population variance; it is obtained by dividing associated sum of squares by the degree of freedom. F value compares the mean square with the residual mean square. The corresponding p-value (Prob>F) is the probability of obtaining F value as or extreme than what we observed in our sample assuming the null hypothesis is true (there are no significant difference of factor effects). The null hypothesis is then reject for small probability values, another common way to evaluate how well the fitted model explains the data is by the determination coefficient (R-square), when the R-square close to 1 means that the predicted values are close to the original values. Furthermore, the R-square is not always indicating that the fitted is good for prediction.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Model fitting for first order design
ce:section.ce:para: It is important to check the capability of the design before running any experiments, the variance function (varfcn in R package) obtained, this function is a useful tool [19] in RSM which provides information for the system to test the variance of the predictions. This function with particular design, an appropriate model, and a different design point from the central to plot the scaled prediction variance. By looking either at a profile plot or at a contour plot, which both are shown in Fig. 2 (a) and (b).

The variance increases, as it goes more out, and it is more suitable at the center. The contour plots of variance function for this design, which is generated using a
cube
function are circular. Hence, this design is rotatable. Then the first-degree model can be fitted. Notably, before having any data, the variance function is a helpful tool to ensure that the model can be fitted.

According to Table 4, none of first-order terms are statistically significant, nor they are together significant (p-value=0.97 in the ANOVA table), so there is no evidence for a specific direction. It is better to move to a better area and collect more data for more reliability.

The initial design was a half fractional factorial with additional center points generated using a
cube
function. So, more information can be obtained by doing a full factorial design for a first-order model. This was done using the
foldover
function, by switching the certain signs of some or all of the coded variables. In this paper, the first experiment was generated using

Note that the other design has different design point [e.g., (6.5, 0.415, and 1200)]. For analysis, a
cube
fraction and a
foldover
design combined using a djoin function. Note that djoin creates a new blocking factor. It is important to include a block effect in the model because there were two separately randomized experiments. From the ANOVA table, the first-order terms are not significant (p-value=0.8294), and the lack of fit test is significant (p-value<0.0001). Response surface experimentation is different from other kinds of experiment designs, in such situation, it is essentially good to have insignificant terms, especially first-order ones. It seems that the process might be close to the optimum region.

The analysis of variance exhibits no significant main effect and there was evidence of curvature in the response surface over the region of study (p-value<0.0001). That is, the null hypothesis

ce:section.ce:section-title: Augmenting further to fit a quadratic response surface
ce:section.ce:para: The optimum design point in some application of the RSM has given as the optimum point. However, it is inappropriate to call these types of studies as an optimization without carrying out the stationary point. It is necessary to clearly explain the goal of the study and the selection of the space of independent variable whenever RSM studies are to be performed without the determination of stationary point [22].

A second-order rotatable design achieved by adding
star
points and by collecting more data at star area, the second-degree model can be fitted. The
star
function in rsm package runs this block for us. The value of parameter alpha (α) in
star
block is orthogonal to the
cube
and
foldover
blocks. The analysis based on combining the
cube
block,
foldover
fraction, and
star
block, and by looking at the variance of the predictions, according to the profile plot or a contour plot, which are shown in Fig. 3 (a), and (b):

The second-order is rotatabledesign with star points added to the complete
2
3
design, since it has a reasonable variance function properties. Based on augmenting this design a quadratic model can be fitted. The response surface was fitted using
rsm
package, the model is based on the
rsm
package must use a specific functions FO, SO, TWI, and PQ (representing first-order, second-order, two-way interaction, and pure quadratic, respectively) as shown in Table 5.

Table 5 shows important quadratic terms (p-value<0.0001) and the lack of fit is now insignificant (p-value=0.16). The second-order response surface model involved a polymer solar cell process in which Polymer concentration, polymer-fullerene ratio, and active layer spinning speed were studied, and the response variable was the cell efficiency. The fitted model is presented as following:

The nature of the stationary point was determined using the signs of the eigenvalues. The estimated stationary point of the response surface is (0.099, −0.975, and 0.061) which is within the design space; this means there is no suggestion of a rising ridge since there is no direction of improvement out of the experimental space, and the predicted response at this stationary point is
y
̂
s
= 5.23
. In the original units, the stationary points are:
Polymer concentration=10+3.5×(0.099)=10.35.
Polymer- fullerene ratio=0.5+0.085×(−0.975)=0.42.
Active layer spinning speed=1600+400×(0.06061492)=1624.

This is in close agreement with the location of the optimum that would be obtained by visual inspection of Fig.4(a)–(c). Since all eigenvalues (−0.150, −0.668, −1.190) are negative, the stationary point is a maximum (as is obvious from the inspection of Fig. 5 (a)–(c)).

Fig. 6 shows the PDPP3T: PCBM device structure. Experimentally, it was found that the optimized device fabrication procedure is 10mg/ml polymer concentration, 1:2 polymer-fullerene ratio and 1600rpm of active layer spinning speed. J-V characteristic curves are shown in Fig. 7 (a)–(c). It is obvious that due to low spinning speed, the active layer turns out to be thick, which may increase absorption as well as JSC. A thick active layer can also increase device resistance/interfacial resistance, which adversely affects the FF of the overall device. In a closely intermixed donor-acceptor blend, the individual stages have a certain extend to allow for efficient transport of charges via percolated pathways towards the respective electrodes [23]. In order to maintain efficient charge transport avoiding recombination within the device, there is always an optimum donor-acceptor ratio and polymer concentration in the solvent. The experimental results successfully coincide with the RSM methodology in device performance optimization.

A bootstrap technique is a helpful tool to validate how well the stationary point is estimated. A 1000 re-fits of the quadratic model simulated for this purpose; then plot the estimated values based on the model in Eq. (1) along with stationary points after the residuals are added back to the fitted values, which are shown in Fig. 8 (a) –(c).

The model coefficient of determination was higher than 0.95, meaning that 97% of the data was explained by the best model.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Confidence region for the location of a stationary point
ce:section.ce:para:
The construction of confidence region on the location of the best combination will allow us determine the optimum conditions in the controllable variable space. The confidence regions on stationary points are a powerful method in determining how well the estimation of the stationary point is, and help us to move to a new region where is better operating conditions occur. A procedure for calculation such regions was presented by Box and Hunter (1954) [24]. The
100 ( 1 - α ) %
Box and Hunter confidence region can be expressed as following:
(3)

confidence region of stationary point as shown in Fig. 9(a) –(c).

As it can be seen, the estimated stationary point fills inside the design space, which is, therefore, a typical situation where it is suitable to construct confidence region for the location of the stationary point.

Optimization of organic solar cells is one of the greatest challenges in OPV technology. Several complex mathematical tools were introduced in order to simplify and understand the solar cell performance. In this work, the goal was to find the optimum polymer solar cell performance through a statistical model. It was found that the RSM to be very useful in precisely optimizing solar device performance. The best model found that 97% of the data was explained, which might help in approaching the optimum device performance efficiently.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: This research was supported by Libyan North American Scholarship Program (LNASP).
